articles.headline: In Cooling China, Loan Sharks Come Knocking
articles.snippet: A growing number of entrepreneurs in China, unable to make payments to illegal lenders, have gone into hiding to avoid physical harm or family dishonor.
articles.abstract: A growing number of entrepreneurs in China, unable to make payments to illegal lenders, have gone into hiding to avoid physical harm or family dishonor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WENZHOU, China — The 300 employees of Aomi Fluid Equipment here were delighted recently when the owner offered an all-expenses-paid, two-day trip to a mountain resort three hours away.

articles.headline: Strauss-Kahn Is Not Charged in French Case
articles.snippet: For the second time this year, Dominique Strauss-Kahn escaped criminal charges of attempted rape, despite what prosecutors in France said was evidence of sexual assault.
articles.abstract: For the second time this year, Dominique Strauss-Kahn escaped criminal charges of attempted rape, despite what prosecutors in France said was evidence of sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the second time this year, legal officials chose on Thursday not to prosecute Dominique Strauss-Kahn on charges of attempted rape, despite what investigators here said was evidence of sexual assault, ending months of scandal that have tarnished a political career that once seemed destined to lead to the French presidency.
articles.byline: By STEVEN ERLANGER and MAÏA de la BAUME

articles.headline: Obama Says Facts Support Accusation of Iranian Plot
articles.snippet: President Obama will push for what he calls the “toughest sanctions” to punish Iranian officials whom he accused of complicity in a suspected plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.
articles.abstract: President Obama will push for what he calls the “toughest sanctions” to punish Iranian officials whom he accused of complicity in a suspected plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama vowed on Thursday to push for what he called the “toughest sanctions” against Iran, saying that the United States had strong evidence that Iranian officials were complicit in an alleged plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

articles.headline: Bank Rules That Serve Two Masters
articles.snippet: A Congress that wants to have it both ways is creating a muddle of the regulations under the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.abstract: A Congress that wants to have it both ways is creating a muddle of the regulations under the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: When there are two powerful factions in Congress, one of which wants to take an action and the other of which wants to avoid it, what should Congress do?

articles.headline: What Compromise?
articles.snippet: Under the hood, automakers are applying technology to meet stiff future mileage standards, but they’re staying mindful of Americans’ love of size and power in their vehicles.
articles.abstract: Under the hood, automakers are applying technology to meet stiff future mileage standards, but they’re staying mindful of Americans’ love of size and power in their vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE formula for better fuel economy in cars has long been a simple equation: the smaller the vehicle, the farther it goes on a gallon of gas.

articles.headline: Resistance From Union in Ford Vote
articles.snippet: Ford’s unionized workers, who haven’t received a raise in years, are upset with the big payouts to the company’s senior management.
articles.abstract: Ford’s unionized workers, who haven’t received a raise in years, are upset with the big payouts to the company’s senior management.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Voting by Ford’s unionized workers on a new contract has been unexpectedly negative, signaling a rejection of its hold-the-line pay provisions and raising at least the possibility that Detroit’s fragile labor peace could be disrupted by a strike.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Squeezed Out in India, Students Turn to U.S.
articles.snippet: The number of Indian students studying in the United States is surging as competition for admission to top Indian institutions has made that goal nearly unattainable.
articles.abstract: The number of Indian students studying in the United States is surging as competition for admission to top Indian institutions has made that goal nearly unattainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Moulshri Mohan was an excellent student at one of the top private high schools in New Delhi. When she applied to colleges, she received scholarship offers of $20,000 from Dartmouth and $15,000 from Smith. Her pile of acceptance letters would have made any ambitious teenager smile: Cornell, Bryn Mawr, Duke, Wesleyan, Barnard and the University of Virginia.

articles.headline: In Michigan, Obama Seeks Some Mileage Out of Auto Bailout
articles.snippet: President Obama has returned to Michigan again and again to argue that his decision to bail out two of the Big Three automakers helped workers across the industrial Midwest.
articles.abstract: President Obama has returned to Michigan again and again to argue that his decision to bail out two of the Big Three automakers helped workers across the industrial Midwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich. — President Obama arrives here on Friday on another visit to Michigan, seeking not only the electoral votes that are essential to his re-election effort, but a platform for a far bigger message.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Eating Disorders a New Front in Insurance Fight
articles.snippet: People with eating disorders like anorexia are fighting insurers to pay for stays in residential treatment centers, an issue that is being considered by an appeals court in California.
articles.abstract: People with eating disorders like anorexia are fighting insurers to pay for stays in residential treatment centers, an issue that is being considered by an appeals court in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: People with eating disorders like anorexia have opened up a new battleground in the insurance wars, testing the boundaries of laws mandating equivalent coverage for mental illnesses.

articles.headline: Friday Night Blight
articles.snippet: Friday is, after Saturday, the loneliest night of the week in the television business, particularly for networks that appeal to younger viewers.
articles.abstract: Friday is, after Saturday, the loneliest night of the week in the television business, particularly for networks that appeal to younger viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saturday night has long been the loneliest night of the week in the television business, but lately it’s been joined by another evening pining for viewers: Fridays.
